justification: The authors state that one of the four construct-focused dictionaries they applied to the LOR texts was “motivation,” taken from LIWC2015, to represent the psychological construct of motivation.
They note that a “personality” dictionary was created from Goldberg’s Big-5 adjective markers and used to quantify personality content within letters.
Among the four construct dictionaries, the paper lists “critical thinking,” saying this LIWC2015 dictionary indexed references to critical/complex thinking in LORs.

measured_by: Ability dictionary compiled from Kyllonen et al., Powers et al., Schmader et al.
justification: Ability/creativity terms (e.g., ‘talent*, intell*’) were assembled into an ‘ability’ dictionary and used as one of the four construct measures applied to the letters.

measured_by: Schmader et al. (2007) Standout words dictionary
justification: The paper explains that one of the nine text dictionaries was ‘standout words,’ sourced from Schmader et al. (2007), to capture language marking applicants as exceptional.
The authors list ‘positive emotional tone’ as one of the five tone dictionaries from LIWC2015 used to gauge overall sentiment in LORs.
They similarly include ‘negative emotional tone’ from LIWC2015 to measure the presence of negative affective language in the letters.
‘Tentativeness’ is identified as a LIWC2015 dictionary applied to the texts to capture hedging or uncertain language.
The paper names ‘certainty’ as another LIWC2015 dictionary used to quantify confident or unequivocal wording in LORs.

Early in the article the authors state that “standardized admissions tests, like the GRE, predict success during and after graduate school,” indicating the GRE is treated as a measure of cognitive ability relevant to graduate achievement.
